@potiuk did you know you can write Pylint disables on the same line as the code?

```python
# pylint: disable=not-callable
resp = getattr(requests, method.lower())(**params)
# pylint: enable=not-callable
```

Equivalent:
```python
resp = getattr(requests, method.lower())(**params)  # pylint: disable=not-callable
```

(in the 2nd case the disable is applied only to that single line, no need to enable again)
Thanks for the hints @BasPH -  I will apply the optimised disables ;)

https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/f0ec5fee2a0e21551311b261b6984042ace106eb/airflow/utils/dag_processing.py#L1240-L1273

We should keep all that logic in a single place.

@ashb   Existing zombie detection works with heartbeat, but the issue i am pointing out is when there is an unexpected db connection error where worker node was unable to update database.
This method update_state() which i have modified now is also called with heartbeat and monitors unfinished tasks to update state of dag run. 
Since, unfinished tasks is already retrieved in update_state() and checked for dependencies, it seemed apt to update the state of task instance here. 

Currently. zombie detection is checking last_updated time on 'jobs' table. But, Task instance table needs to be updated and checked as the failure occurred in worker while updating Task instance table
Updated to one-liners :D
@samuelwbock are you skill working on this PR? There are conflicts to resolve

@BasPH @ashb - I also added a few minor changes to make the bash script more "resilient" - now you can run it from any directory and it will work fine, I also added the usual -uo pipefail (I usually add set -euo pipefail for all bash scripts). I also disabled -x by default and replaced it with more informative messages (still left commented set -x so that you can uncomment it if needed)

We implanted similar feature in our system however this PR is much more extensive and I'm glad it will be integrated to Airflow.
I'm just commenting to be notified when the PR is merged.

I'm sorry if it seemed like I was considering it inconvenient and a bad idea, it's not. It's negligible effort, but I do think it's also negligible value.

While migrations are indeed part of the codebase, they're definitely not in the scope of standard software development standards. You said you didn't want to lower the boundaries, but that's sort of what happened: very long modules names starting with numbers are now allowed inside _all_ the codebase, despite this being acceptable only inside migrations. That's why I said migrations should use a different set of pylint configurations (or none at all, but the first is better). 

I completely agree with all your motives, despite this docstring in particular being totally unrelated to the issue itself and IMO better as a line comment like it was before. But it's OK. I think git/JIRA is the right place to document the value decision anyway. 

I see the doscstring currently being merged is not there because it's a good docstring, it's there because I need pylint to pass. This means pylint needs adjustments to become more useful.

Will rebase and push.

> I see the doscstring currently being merged is not there because it's a good docstring, it's there because I need pylint to pass. This means pylint needs adjustments to become more useful.

I guess this is also related to how much effort I put. Let me reformulate the docs in this migration.

Alright, there it is. I think this docstring is now more useful and actually related to the method itself and not the implementation detail.

I still think module names should be kept strict in the main codebase, but if this is the kind of dosctring that gets enforced, they can be helpful for future maintainers indeed.
@ashb -> are you ok (at least for now) with not adding git to the picture? I'd love to merge that one. That can make developer's live a bit easier ;).
Oh yeah more than happy with this as it is.

@ashb fyi, just in case you missed notification, I think this is good to go (regarding all prior issues raised).   I have left the last conversation unresolved just in you think there is anything further needed there.

@ashb 
It seems semantics of _check_and_change_state_before_execution function is to change the task state to None if RUN_DEPS are not met (so that it can be rescheduled). But It does not change anything if QUEUE_DEPS are not met. i.e task would remain in its current state. As per my understanding a task run(ti.run) can be triggered either by scheduler or through cmd line. And in _check_and_change_state_before_execution function we might not want to change the  state (if QUEUE_DEPS are not met) for tasks trigged via commandline.So it leaves their state as it is.
We have seen couple of instances where task remained stuck in queued state and is picked up by scheduler after restart.
We will debug it further and will check for alternate solutions.
Just wanted to check if this understanding makes sense to you
